frontmatter.title: Assignment: Global average budgets in the CESM pre-industrial control simulation

abbreviations.EMIC: Earth System Model of Intermediate Complexity

children.value: Students completing this assignment will gain the following skills and concepts:
Continued practice working with the Jupyter notebook
Familiarity with atmospheric output from the
More complete comparison of the global energy budget in the
Validation of the annual cycle of surface temperature against observations
e a hypothesis about these global temperature variations
Python programming skills: basic xarray usage: opening gridded dataset and taking averages
In a local copy of this notebook (on the JupyterHub or your own device)
add your answers in additional cells
Remember to set your cell types to
in your code to explain your method as necessary.
Remember to actually answer the questions.
that contains your text, your code, and your figures.

If yes, save again and submit your notebook file
If no, fix the errors and try again.
Problem 1: The global energy budget in the

children.label: Problem 1: The global energy budget in the CESM control simulation

children.value: of each of the following quantities, and compare them to the observed values from the Trenberth and Fasullo (2012) figure in the course notes:
Reflected Solar Radiation at the top of atmosphere
Solar Radiation Refelected by Clouds and Atmosphere
e this as the difference between the reflected radiation at the top of atmosphere and reflected radiation at the surface)
e this as the residual of your budget, i.e. what’s left over after accounting for all other absorption and reflection)
You will find this in the field called
You will find this in the field called
Note we will look more carefully at atmospheric absorption and emission processes
er. You do not need to try to calcu
e terms such as “Emitted by Atmosphere” or “Atmospheric Window”
Based on your results above, answer the following questions:
Summarize in your own words what you think are the most important similarities and differences of the global energy budgets in the
Problem 2: Verifying the annual cycle in global mean surface temperature against observations

children.label: Problem 2: Verifying the annual cycle in global mean surface temperature against observations

children.value: In the class notes we plotted the
timeseries of global mean surface temperature

. The purpose of this exercise is to verify that this phenomenon is also found in the observed temperature record. If so, then we can conclude that it is a real feature of Earth’s climate and not an artifact of the numerical model.
For observations, we will use the

Reanalysis data is really a blend of observations and output from numerical weather prediction models. It represents our “best guess” at conditions over the whole globe, including regions where observations are very sparse.
The necessary data are all served up over the internet. We will look at monthly climatologies averaged over the 30 year period 1981 - 2010.
You can browse the available data here:
is contained in a file called
, which is found in the collection called
Here’s a link directly to the catalog page for this data file:
link. A page opens up with lots of information about the contents of the file. The
is what we need to read the data into our Python session. For example, this code opens the file and displays a list of the variables it contains:

import xarray as xr
url = "http://www.esrl.noaa.gov/psd/thredds/dodsC/Datasets/ncep.reanalysis.derived/surface_gauss/air.2m.mon.ltm.nc"
ncep_air2m = xr.open_dataset(url, decode_times=False)

ncep_air2m

children.value: . The time dimension is calendar months. But note that the
grid is not the same as our model output!
Think about how you will handle calcu
ing the global average of these data.
ke a well-labeled timeseries graph of the global-averaged observed average surface air temperature climatology.
Verify that the annual cycle we found in the
ion also exists in the observations.
In your own words, suggest a plausible physical explanation for why this annual cycle exists.
